item.title: Customize your Jekyll blog - Part II
item.description:
This tutorial is part of a series of tutorials on how to build, maintain and customize a Jekyll blog. If you haven’t read the previous ones, please go through them:

  • Build your own blog with Jekyll
  • A better Jekyll workflow with gulp
  • Customize your Jekyll blog - Part I
  • Customize your Jekyll blog - Part II

You can view or download the source files on the Jekyll tutorial github repo.

The post header

Let’s begin by styling our post header. First, we’ll remove the blog title and add some navigation instead. For this, we’ll create a new layout for our posts called default_post.html that we’ll place in the _layouts folder.

And add some style for the navigation in our _sass/_theme.scss file.

We’ll now change the default layout of the post layout located in _layouts/post.html and make some other changes like adding a full width background image for the header.

I know, it looks bad so let’s add some style to our header.

You should now see something like this.

The post content

Now that we have a nice header, let’s style our post content by increasing the font size, add some space and styling our links.

Finally, we are going to change our syntax highlight with the light-solar-theme found in the @mattvh github repository. Create a _light-solar-syntax-highlighting.scss file in the _sass directory and fill it with this code:

To make it active, we’ll replace the imported syntax highlighting file in our css/main.scss by the new one.

“Et voila!”

That’s it for this series of tutorials showing how to customize your Jekyll blog. I hope you enjoyed it :)

item.title: A better Jekyll workflow with Gulp
item.description:
This tutorial is part of a series of tutorials on how to build, maintain and customize a Jekyll blog. If you haven’t read the previous ones, please go through them:

  • Build your own blog with Jekyll
  • A better Jekyll workflow with gulp
  • Customize your Jekyll blog - Part I
  • Customize your Jekyll blog - Part II

Summary

In this tutorial we will see how to maintain your Jekyll blog efficiently with glup. I will explain how to:

  • reload your browser automatically each time you save changes
  • switch easily between local and production settings
  • minify your images
  • deploy your blog updates easily

You can view or download the source files on the Jekyll tutorial github repo.

Automatic browser reload

In this part, we are going to make gulp watch our files, and when a change is saved, reload our browser in order to see the result directly without to do it manually.

For this, we will use a gulpfile.js found on github and wrote by @shakyShane as a base that I’ll change a little for our needs.

Create a file called package.json like this:

Now, install the dependencies with:

You should now see a new folder called node_modules.

Last step is to exclude this new files from the Jekyll build. So open your _config.yml file and add this line at the end:

As we now user gulp-sass to generate our final css file, we’ll also need to remove those first 3 lines of our css/main.scss to prevent an error when compiling.

That’s it! You now just have to fire gulp in your terminal. A new tab will open automatically and will update automatically as well when you save changes in your files. Try it by making some changes to the _sass/_base.scss file or the index.html file.

Switch easily between local and production

When working locally on your computer, you need to set your site.url like http://localhost:3000. But before to deploy your blog on github you need to update the site.url with your production url like http://mydomain.com. This can become very annoying. So we’re going to fix this.

Create a new file called _config_dev.yml at the root of your project with two lines:

The two same lines in your _config.yml should be set with your production settings.

Now, we will update our gulpfile.js so that Jekyll use our two config files. Open it and change the jekyll-build task like this:

Done! Now you won’t have to bother anymore switching manually between local and production url.

Minify your images

To minify our images we will use the gulp-imagemin plugin made by @sindresorhus.

First we have to install the plugin.

Then, add those lines to your gulpfile.js:

Now update the jekyll-build task so it launches the minify-images task before.

Create an _images folder where you will store your new un-minified images. Don’t put them anymore on the img folder, it is now only a transition folder.

Finally, update your gulp watch task so that it watches your _images folder.

Deploy on github

To automate our github deploy, we will use the gulp-shell plugin made by @sun-zheng-an.

First, install the plugin.

And add those lines to your gulpfile.js:

Because we added our _config_dev.yml file to the Jekyll build task, we also have to add a task for building our production blog without this file.

Now, you just have to fire gulp deploy on your terminal to update your blog.

That’s it for this tutorial. Stay tuned for next one.

item.title: Build your own blog with Jekyll
item.description:
This tutorial is part of a series of tutorials on how to build, maintain and customize a Jekyll blog. If you haven’t read the previous ones, please go through them:

  • Build your own blog with Jekyll
  • A better Jekyll workflow with gulp
  • Customize your Jekyll blog - Part I
  • Customize your Jekyll blog - Part II

Summary

In this tutorial, I’ll show you how to:

  • build a blog with Jekyll,
  • write our first blog post,
  • add disqus to our post,
  • and finally, host it for free on Github.

You can view or download the source files on the Jekyll tutorial github repo.

Building a blog with Jekyll

Fist we need to install Jekyll on our computer.

Now that Jekyll is installed, we can generate the blog.

Then go into the generated folder and launch the Jekyll server.

Now you can go to http://127.0.0.1:4000/ and see your blog in action!

Now we want to customize it. All the config informations are in the _config.yml file, located at the root of your folder. Let’s open it in our favorite editor and update it.

We are also going to get rid of the about page because we don’t need it. Simply delete the about.md file in the root of your directory.

Stop and relaunch your jekyll serve command and see the result!

That’s it for the first part! We’ll keep it simple for now and won’t customize the theme of our blog. But stay tuned, I’ll write another tutorial explaining how to do this soon ;)

Writing our first post

First, we need to create the post file in the _posts directory. Post file name needs to follow this convention YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP, so name it like this 2015-11-18-our-first-awesome-post.md.

Now, open the file in your editor and add this at the beginning:

This is an important part of your post, it won’t be displayed on the page but will be used by Jekyll while generating your blog, particularly when listing all the posts in the home page.

After this, you can begin to write your first awesome post using the markdown syntax. I won’t go in details on writing markdown as you can find a lot of material explaining this. You could have a look at the github help page for markdown for example.

I’ll just explain how to manage your post images that you want to store locally. You probably already know that to insert an image in your post you’ll use this syntax ![image title](http://image-url). But if you store your images locally, you more likely use a relative url like this one ![image title](/img/image-name.jpg).

So we are going to create an img folder at the root where we’ll store all our images. It will be automatically copied to the _site folder (more on this at the last part of this tutorial).

Now you can add a local image to your post like this ![image title]({{ site.url }}/img/image-name.jpg)

Hosting our blog on github

Now that we know how to add content to our blog, we want to make it live so that we can share our awesome content with others.

Go to your github account and create a new repository.

Then copy the ssh url (or https if you prefer) of your new repository.

Now, open a terminal at the root of your blog project, go to the _site folder and create a new git repository.

Add a remote to your git repository using the url that you copied earlier on github.

Update your site url in _config.yml.

We now need to create the gh-pages branch and then our first commit.

Finally, we push it to github.

You should now be able to see it live at http://username.github.io/blog!

Adding disqus to our post

Now that our post is live, we want to add the possibility for the reader to comment. We’ll use Disqus for that.

First, create an account and then register a new site.

You should then be redirected on the installation page asking you to choose your platform. Choose Universal Code and copy the code of the first step.

Then we need to add this code to our post template file located at _layouts/post.html. Open this file and add at the end of the <article> block the copied code between {% if page.comments %} and {% endif %}.

To make it more flexible, we’ll make some change to the disqus code.

And add the corresponding variable to our _config.yml file.

Now we just have to add comments: true to the front matter of our post and the disqus comment section will load automatically.

Run jekyll build, commit the changes, and push the _site folder to github.

That’s it for this tutorial. Stay tuned for next one.

Bonus: Redirect your custom domain name to your blog

If you own a custom domain name, you’ll probably want to redirect it to your blog. For example, you could redirect blog.yourdomain.com to your github page.

In order to do this, you first need to create a CNAME file at the root of your project. Add one line containing your domain url. So in our case blog.yourdomain.com.

Commit the file and push it to github.

Now, go to your registrar and update the DNS records of your domain name. Create a CNAME record like this:

Wait a little and your subdomain should redirect to your blog. Don’t forget to update your site url in _config.yml.
